head.title: The Case of Wen Ho Lee: The Questions Linger

hedline.hl1: The Case of Wen Ho Lee: The Questions Linger

abstract.p: Letter by Morton Sobell, who was convicted of conspiracy in Rosenberg spy case, responds to Times admission of shortcomings in coverage of Wen Ho Lee national security case; recalls that, 50 years ago, Times also neglected to get dispassionate view of government's case

block.p: Your Sept. 26 note ''From the Editors'' on The Times's handling of the Wen Ho Lee case acknowledges that you could have moved ''to open a second line of reporting, particularly among scientists inside and outside the government'' to get a more objective view of the case.
Some 50 years ago, at the Rosenberg atom spy trial, The Times also neglected to get a dispassionate view of the government's case.

Your Sept. 26 note ''From the Editors'' on The Times's handling of the Wen Ho Lee case acknowledges that you could have moved ''to open a second line of reporting, particularly among scientists inside and outside the government'' to get a more objective view of the case.
Some 50 years ago, at the Rosenberg atom spy trial, The Times also neglected to get a dispassionate view of the government's case.

A memo from the F.B.I. director to the attorney general dated May 14, 1954, after the Rosenbergs were tried and executed, quotes Gen. Leslie R. Groves, the head of the Los Alamos Laboratory, who clearly thought the Rosenbergs guilty: ''I think the data that went out in the case of the Rosenbergs was of minor value. I would never say that publicly.''
Information of minor value would have hardly sufficed to impose the death penalty on two people. What if The Times had learned of this view and published it at the time of the trial?
The writer was convicted of conspiracy in the Rosenberg case and served for 18 1/2 years.
